revisions.rev:
{{Other uses|Nur al-Din (disambiguation){{!}}Nur al-Din}}
'''Noor al-Deen''' is a citizen of [[Syria]] wounded when he was captured by counter-terrorism officials at a raid on a "[[Faisalabad safe house]]" when [[Abu Zubaydah]] was captured.<ref name=Cbs> {{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/29/politics/washingtonpost/main4901154.shtml | title=Officials: Waterboarding Foiled No Plot | publisher=[[CBS News]] | author=Peter Finn, Joby Warrick, Julie Tate | date=2009-03-29 | accessdate=2009-03-30 | quote= }} [http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cbsnews.com%2Fstories%2F2009%2F03%2F29%2Fpolitics%2Fwashingtonpost%2Fmain4901154.shtml&date=2009-03-30 mirror] </ref> According to the ''[[Washington Post]]'' Noor al-Deen, like Abu Zubaydah, was sent to [[Morocco]] by the [[CIA]], so he too could be subjected to "[[enhanced interrogation techniques]]"
According to the ''Washington Post'' Noor al-Deen admired Abu Zubaydah, was guileless and unguarded to his interrogators and was the source of much of information analysts initially believed about him. [[John Kiriakou]], a CIA officer who participated in the raid said: :{| class="wikitable" border="1" | :"He was frightened - mostly over what we were going to do with him. He had come to the conclusion that his life was over." |}
Historian [[Andy Worthington]], author of ''[[The Guantanamo Files]]'', confirmed that Noor al-Deen had not been sent to Guantanamo.<ref name=Fff2009-03-30> {{cite news | url=http://www.fff.org/comment/com0903m.asp | title=Abu Zubaydah and the Futility of Torture | publisher=[[Future of Freedom Foundation]] | author= | date=2009-03-30 | accessdate=2009-03-30 | quote= }} [http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fff.org%2Fcomment%2Fcom0903m.asp&date=2009-03-30 mirror] </ref> According to Worthington, Noor Al-Deen was the teenager whom [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Abdullah Almalki]] described as being held [[extrajudicial detention]] in Syria's [[Palestinian Branch]] military prison.<ref name="kerry">Pither, Kerry. "Dark Days: The Story of Four Canadians Tortured in the Name of Fighting Terror", 2008.</ref>
[[Tunisian captives in Guantanamo|Tunisian captive]] [[Salah Bin Al Hadi Asasi]] faced the allegation that he was ''"recruited to fight the [[jihad]]"'' by "Noor Deen" at a mosque in [[Turin]], [[Italy]], in February 2001.<ref name=CsrtSummaryOfEvidenceSalahBinAlHadiAsasi> {{cite web | author=[[OARDEC]] | url=http://www.dod.mil/pubs/foi/detainees/csrt_arb/000001-000100.pdf#57-58 | publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] | title=Summary of Evidence for Salah Bin Al Hadi Asasi | pages='''pages 57â58''' | date=2004-10-04 | quote=In February 2001, the detainee was recruited to fight the [[jihad]] in [[Afghanistan]] by Noor-Deen, a known [[al Qaida recruiter]], at the [[w:Via Berreti mosque|Via Berreti mosque]] in Turin. }}</ref>
